Orbitolite body, but also affords some additional information
of much interest. For we see in the first place, that the growth of
the sarcode and the addition of new parts, may take place in
the direction of the <s><u>_</u></s> centre, where a free edge is exposed at the <u>inner</u> margin of any zone, as well as in the peripheral direction
from the normal <u>outer</u> margin. Secondly the reparation <u>nisus</u>
seems always to tend towards the production of a disk, whose
shape shall approach the circular, whatever may be the form of
the fragment which serves as its foundation; thus showing
that notwithstanding the repetition and independence of
the separate parts of these organisms, each cluster, whether
large or small, is an interger, having an archetypal symmetry
to which it tends to conform, thus strongly reminding us of the laws of
crystallisation. And thirdly, the plan by which this recurrence
to the discoidal form is provided-for, seems partly to consist in
the limitation of the new growth to the natural margins of the
zones; no such growth taking-place from the edge of a fracture
which has crossed the zones transversely, although it may proceed
from the remains of a zone which has been broken-off by a fracture
